description:
From Middle English supplien, borrowed from Old French soupleer, souploier, from Latin supplere (“to fill up, make full, complete, supply”).
The Middle English spelling was modified to conform to Latin etymology.

examples: A supply of good drinking water is essential.
She said, "China has always had a freshwater supply problem with 20 percent of the world’s population but only 7 percent of its freshwater".

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural) An amount of money provided, as by Parliament or Congress, to meet the annual national expenditures.
Somebody, such as a teacher or clergyman, who temporarily fills the place of another; a substitute.

verbs.description: supply (third-person singular simple present supplies, present participle supplying, simple past and past participle supplied)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide (something), to make (something) available for use.
examples: to supply money for the war
to supply a furnace with fuel; to supply soldiers with ammunition

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill up, or keep full.
examples: Rivers are supplied by smaller streams.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To compensate for, or make up a deficiency of.
(transitive) To serve instead of; to take the place of.
examples: The sun was set, and Vesper, to supply  His absent beams, had lighted up the sky.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fill temporarily; to serve as substitute for another in, as a vacant place or office; to occupy; to have possession of.

adverbs.description: supply (comparative more supply, superlative most supply)

entries.meaning: Supplely: in a supple manner, with suppleness.
examples: His voice was playful and full; his back was bent supply.
